verses.text: , cap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:642
verses.text: 2 - note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:643
verses.text: )  The early disappearance of the Christian agapae may probably be attributed to the terrible abuse of the word here referred to, by the licentious Carpocratians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:644
verses.text: The genuine agapae were of apostolic origin ( Pet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:645
verses.text: 2 - ; Jude ), but were often abused by hypocrites, even under the apostolic eye ( Corinthians :).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:646
verses.text: In the Gallican Church, a survival or relic of these feasts of charity is seen in the pain béni; and, in the Greek churches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:647
verses.text: in the ἀντίδωρον or eulogiae distributed to non-communicants at the close of the Eucharist, from the loaf out of which the bread of oblation is supposed to have been cut.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:648
verses.text: 3  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:649
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:650
verses.text: )  Next, he treats of the Marcionites, who rejected marriage on the ground that the material creation is in itself evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:651
verses.text: Promising elsewhere to deal with this general false principle, he refutes Marcion, and with him the Greeks who have condemned the generative law of nature, specifying Heraclitus, Empedocles, the Sibyl, Homer, and others; but he defends Plato against Marcion, who represents him as teaching the depravity of matter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:652
verses.text: He proceeds to what the dramatists have exhibited of human misery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:653
verses.text: He shows the error of those who represent the Pythagoreans as on that account denying themselves the intimacies of conjugal society; for he says they practiced this restraint, only after having given themselves a family.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:654
verses.text: He explains the prohibition of the bean, by Pythagoras, on the very ground, that it occasioned sterility in women according to Theophrastus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:655
verses.text: Clement expounds the true meaning of Christ's words, perverted by those who abstained from marriage not in honour of encraty, but as an insane impeachment of the divine wisdom in the material creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:656
verses.text: 4  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:657
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:658
verses.text: )  He refutes the Carpocratians, also, in their slanders against the deacon Nicolas, showing that the Nicolaitans had abused his name and words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:659
verses.text: Likewise, concerning Matthias, he exposes a similar abuse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:660
verses.text: He castigates one who seduced a maiden into impurity by an absurd perversion of Scripture, and thoroughly exposes this blasphemous abuse of the apostolic text.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:661
verses.text: He subjoins another refutation of one of those heretics, and allows that some might adopt the opinion of his dupes, if, as the Valentinians would profess, only spiritual communion were concerned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:662
verses.text: Seeing, however, that these heretics, and the followers of Prodicus, who wrongfully call themselves gnostics, claimed a practical indulgence in all manner of disgusting profligacies, he convicts them by arguments derived from right reason and from the Scriptures, and by human laws as well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:663
verses.text: Further, he exposes the folly of those who pretended that the less honourable parts of man are not the work of the Creator, and overwhelms their presumption by abundant argument, exploding, at the same time, their corruptions of the sacred text of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:664
verses.text: 5  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:665
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:666
verses.text: )  To relieve himself of a more particular struggle with each individual heresy, he proceeds to reduce them under two heads: () Those who teach a reckless mode of life (ἀδιαφόρως ζῆν), and () those who impiously affect continence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:667
verses.text: To the first, he opposes the plain propriety and duty of a decorous way of living continently; showing, that as it cannot be denied that there are certain abominable and filthy lusts, which, as such, must be shunned, therefore there is no such thing as living "indifferently" with respect to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:668
verses.text: He who lives to the flesh, moreover, is condemned; nor can the likeness and image of God be regained, or eternal life be ensured, save by a strict observance of divine precepts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:669
verses.text: Further, our author shows that true Christian liberty consists, not, as they vociferate, in self-indulgence, but, on the contrary, is founded in an entire freedom from perturbations of mind and passion, and from all filthy lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:670
verses.text: 6  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:671
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:672
verses.text: )  As to the second class of heretics, he reproves the contemners of God's ordinance, who boast of a false continence, and scorn holy matrimony and the creation of a family.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:673
verses.text: He contends with them by the authority of St.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:674
verses.text: John, and first answers objections of theirs, based on certain apocryphal sayings of Christ to Salome; next, somewhat obscurely, he answers their notions of laws about marriage imposed in the Old Law, and, as they pretend, abrogated in the New; thirdly, he rebukes their perpetual clatter about the uncleanness of conjugal relations; and, fourth, he pulverizes their arguments derived from the fact, that the children of the resurrection "neither marry, nor are given in marriage".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:675
verses.text: Then he gives his attention to another class of heretics boasting that they followed the example of Christ, and presuming to teach that marriage is of the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:676
verses.text: He expounds the exceptional celibacy of the Messiah, by the two natures of the Godman, which need nothing but a reverent statement to expose the fallacy of arguing from His example in this particular, seeing He, alone, of all the sons of men, is thus supreme over all considerations of human nature, pure and simple, as it exists in the sons of Adam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:677
verses.text: Moreover, He espoused the Church, which is His  wife.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:678
verses.text: Clement expounds very wisely those sayings of our Lord which put honour upon voluntary celibacy, where the gift has been imparted, for His better service.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:679
verses.text: And here let it be noted, how continually the heresies of these times seem to turn on this matter of the sexes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:680
verses.text: It is impossible to cleanse a dirty house, without raising a dust and a bad smell; and heathenism, which had made lust into a religion, and the worship of its gods a school of gross vice, penetrating all classes of society, could not be exorcised, and give place to faith, hope and charity, without this process of conflict, in which Clement distinguishes himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:681
verses.text: At the same time, the wisdom of our Lord's precepts and counsels are manifest, in this history.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:682
verses.text: Alike He taught the sanctity and blessedness of marriage and maternity, and the exceptional blessedness of the celibate when received as a gift of God, for a peculiar ministry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:683
verses.text: Thus heathen morals were rebuked and castigated, womanhood was lifted to a sphere of unwonted honour, and the home was created and sanctified in the purity and chastity of the Christian wife; while yet a celibate chastity was recognised as having a high place in the Christian system.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:684
verses.text: The Lord prescribes to all, whether married or unmarried, a law of discipline and evangelical encraty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:685
verses.text: The Christian homes of England and America may be pointed out, thank God, as illustrating the divine wisdom; while the degraded monasteries of Italy and Spain and South America, with the horrible history of enforced celibacy in the Latin priesthood, are proofs of the unwisdom of those who imported into the Western churches the very heresies and abortive argumentations which Clement disdains, while he pulverizes them and blows them away, thoroughly purging his floor, and burning up this chaff.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:686
verses.text: 7  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:687
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:688
verses.text: )  Here it is specially important to observe what Clement demonstrates, not only from the teachings of the apostles, of Elijah and Samuel and the Master Himself, but, finally and irrefragably, from the apostolic example.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:689
verses.text: He names St.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:690
verses.text: Peter here as elsewhere, and notes his memorable history as a married man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:691
verses.text: He supposes St.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:692
verses.text: Paul himself to have been married; and he instances St.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:693
verses.text: Philip the deacon, and his married daughters, besides giving the right exposition of a passage which Carpocrates had shamefully distorted from its plain significance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:694
verses.text: 8  (See p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:695
verses.text: , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:696
verses.text: )  He passes to a demonstration of the superiority of Christian continence over the sort of self-constraint lauded by Stoics and other philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:697
verses.text: God only can enable man to practice a genuine continence, not merely contending with depraved lusts, but eradicating them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:698
verses.text: Here follow some interesting examples drawn from the brahmins and fakirs of India; interesting tokens, by the way, of the assaults the Gospel had already made upon their strongholds about the Ganges.

verses.text: And, as for a Gospel written in the Hebrew tongue, Clement could not read Hebrew; the single citation he makes out of it, being, probably, at second hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:711
verses.text: Greatly to the point is the argument of Lardner, therefore, who says, as settling the question of the value of these books, "If Clement, who lived at Alexandria, and was so well acquainted with almost all sorts of books, had (but a slight, or) no knowledge at all of them, how obscure must they have been; how little regarded by Catholic Christians".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:715
verses.text: )  Ingenious is Clement's exposition of that saying of our Lord, "Where two or three are met together in my name," etc.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:716
verses.text: He explodes a monstrous exposition of the text, and ingeniously applies it to the Christian family.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:717
verses.text: The husband and the wife living in chaste matrimony, and the child which God bestows, are three in sweet society, who may claim and enjoy the promise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:718
verses.text: This reflects great light upon the Christian home, as it rose, like a flower, out of the "Church in the house".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:719
verses.text: Family prayers, the graces before and after meat, the hymn "On lighting the lamps at eventide," and the complines, or prayers at bedtime, are all the products of the divine contract to be with the "two or three" who are met in His name to claim that inconceivably precious promise.

verses.text: He turns the tables on his foul antagonists; showing them that this very law obliges the Catholic Christian to separate himself alike from the abominations of the heathen, and from the depraved heretics who abuse the word of God, and "wrest the Scriptures to their own destruction".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:727
verses.text: This eleventh chapter of the third book abounds in Scriptural citations and expositions, and is to be specially praised for asserting the purity of married life, in connection with the inspired law concerning fasting and abstinence ( Cor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:733
verses.text: Against poor Tatian's garrulity, he proves the sanctity of marriage, alike in the New and the Old Testaments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:734
verses.text: A curious argument he adduces against the ceremonial washing prescribed by the  law (Lev.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:735

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:736
verses.text: He considers that particular ceremonial law a protest against the polygamy which God tolerated, but never authorized, under Moses; and its abrogation (i-e:, by the Synod of Jerusalem), is a testimony that there is no uncleanness, whatever, in the chaste society of the married pair, in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:737
verses.text: He rescues other texts from the profane uses of the heretics, proving that our duty to abstain from laying up treasures here, merely layouts the care of the poor and needy; and that the saying, that "the children of the kingdom neither marry nor are given in marriage," respects only their estate after the resurrection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:738
verses.text: So the command about "caring for the things of God," is harmonized with married life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:739
verses.text: But our author dwells on the apostle's emphatic counsels against second marriages.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:740
verses.text: It is noteworthy how deeply Clement's orthodoxy has rooted itself in the Greek churches, where the clergy must be once married, but are not permitted to marry a second time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:741
verses.text: A curious objection is met and dismissed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:742
verses.text: The man who excused himself "because he had married a wife," was a great card for heretical manipulations; but no need of saying that Clement knows how to turn this, also, upon their own hands.

verses.text: But Clement does not treat him as he does the vulgar and licentious errorist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:752
verses.text: He reproves him for his use of the Gospel according to the Egyptians, incidentally testifying to the Catholic recognition of only four Gospels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:753
verses.text: He refutes a Platonic idea of Cassian, as to the pre-existence of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:754
verses.text: Also, he promises a full explanation, elsewhere, of "the coats of skins" (which Cassian seems to have thought the flesh itself), wherewith Adam and Eve were clothed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:755
verses.text: Lardner refers us to Beausobre for a curious discussion of this matter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:756
verses.text: Clement refutes a false argument from Christ's hyperbole of hatred to wife and children and family ties, and also gives lucid explanations of passages from Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezra, which had been wrested to heretical abuse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:757
verses.text: In a similar manner, he overthrows what errorists had built upon Job's saying, "who can bring a clean thing out of the unclean;" as also their false teachings on the texts, "In sin hath my mother conceived me," "the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul," and the apostolic instance of the athlete who is "temperate in all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:761
verses.text: )  He proclaims the purity of physical generation, because of the parturition of the Blessed Virgin; castigating the docetism of Cassian, who had presumed to speak of the body of Jesus as a phantasm, and the grosser blasphemies of Marcion and Valentinus, equally destructive to the Christ of the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:762
verses.text: He overturns the whims of these latter deceivers, about Adam's society with his wife, and concludes that our Lord's assumption of the flesh of His mother, was a sufficient corroboration of that divine law by which the generations of mankind are continued.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:763
verses.text: 16  (See p, , note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:764
verses.text: )  From all which Clement concludes that his two classes of heretics are alike wanderers from Catholic orthodoxy; whether, on the one hand, under divers pretexts glorifying an unreal continence  against honourable marriage, or, on the other, persuading themselves as speciously to an unlimited indulgence of their sinful lusts and passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:765
verses.text: Once more he quotes the Old Testament and the New, which denounce uncleanness, but not the conjugal relations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:766
verses.text: He argues with indignation upon those who degrade the estate to which a bishop is called as "the husband of one wife, ruling his own house and children well".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book III 1:767
verses.text: Then he reverts to his idea of "the two or three," maintaining that a holy marriage makes the bishop's home "a house of the Lord" (see note , p.

verses.text: And he concludes the book by repeating his remonstrance against the claim of these heretics to be veritable Gnostics,—a name he will by no means surrender to the enemies of truth.
